solution_line_template: If {total_fruits} fruits were evenly split between {num_fruit_types} types of fruits, then I bought {total_fruits}/{num_fruit_types} = <<{total_fruits}/{num_fruit_types}={fruits_per_type}>>{fruits_per_type} units of each fruit
If 1 orange costs ${orange_price} then {fruits_per_type} oranges will cost ${orange_price} * {fruits_per_type} = $<<{orange_price}*{fruits_per_type}={orange_total}>>{orange_total}

If my total bill was ${total_bill} and I spent ${orange_total} on oranges then I spent ${total_bill} - ${orange_total} = $<<{total_bill}-{orange_total}={spent_on_apples_watermelons}>>{spent_on_apples_watermelons} on the other 2 fruit types.
Assuming the price of watermelon is W, and knowing that you can buy 4 apples for the same price and that the price of one apple is A, then 1W=4A

If we know we bought {watermelons_bought} watermelons and {apples_bought} apples for ${spent_on_apples_watermelons}, then we know that ${spent_on_apples_watermelons} = {watermelons_bought}W + {apples_bought}A
Knowing that 1W=4A, then we can convert the above to ${spent_on_apples_watermelons} = {watermelons_bought}(4A) + {apples_bought}A
Then we know the price of one apple (A) is ${spent_on_apples_watermelons}/{sum_coeff}= $<<{spent_on_apples_watermelons}/{sum_coeff}={answer}>>{answer}
